html
Class Table

java.lang.Object
  html.Table

public class Table
extends java.lang.Object

This class allows us to acces an html table dynamicly. When you have finished building the table using the methods in this class you can get its contents as string using the toString function. The basic approach is to declare a new table object with a given number of columns and then start using the addItem function to add cells to the table. You can then choose to force the move to the next row or not, perhaps if you want a couple of empty rows for design purposes. Then as final you would do a last nextRow, this is required, otherwise the contents of the last row you added are lost. You can then pass the table into a String using: String s1 = ""; tablename.nextRow() s1 += tablename

Author:
Ict09

Table

public Table(int cols)
Creates a new table

Parameters:
cols - The number of columns wide this table is supposed to be. This can only be set trough this constructor.

public void addRedStarToLast()

public void addRequiredPartOne()

addRequiredPartTwo

public void addRequiredPartTwo()

nextRow

public void nextRow()
Creates a new row in this table and moves the cursor towards this row. At the end of the table it is necesary to use this function, otherwise the last row inside the table isn't shown. At other times you can use this if you want some empty rows for spacing.

addItem

public void addItem(java.lang.Object content)
Adds a new item to the table. It also moves the column cursor to this item. If there are no new columns in the current row, we move to the next row.

Parameters:
content - The item to put inside this table.

addThItem

public void addThItem(java.lang.Object content)
In the table there is one row for headers. With this function you can create these headers. If there are any headers set, they are automatically added to the output of this table.

Parameters:
content -

setItem

public void setItem(java.lang.Object content,
                    int row,
                    int column)
Sets an item at the given position in this table. It does not alter the current row or column cursors in any way. Please be aware that the current content is overwritten when using this function on an existing cell in the table.

Parameters:
content - the content to set inside the cell.
row - The row to move to. Starting at 0
column - the column to move to. Starting at 0

addToItem

public void addToItem(java.lang.Object content,
                      int row,
                      int column)
Add an item to the given position in this table. It does not alter the current row or column cursors in any way.

Parameters:
content - the content to set inside the cell.
row - The row to move to. Starting at 0
column - the column to move to. Starting at 0

addToLastItem

public void addToLastItem(java.lang.Object content)
Adds an extra string to the current open cell. This string is always added to the item you added with a previous addItem.

Parameters:
content - The content to add to the cell.

setMode

public void setMode(boolean alternating)
The line alternating mode provides alternating colors in table rows. This is helpful when constructing tables that present data. The default is false, so if you do not need this functionality it is not necesary to use this method.

Parameters:
alternating - true if it should draw alternating colors, false if not.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
This method turns the entire table into a html formatted table. it returns this table as a string. This function overides the default Object.toString() function, making it possible to type lines like. String s1 = "hello" + new Table(3);

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

setAlignment

public void setAlignment(Type alignment)
Set the type of alignment

Parameters:
alignment - the type of alignment to set, you can get an alignment inside this class like Table._TYPE_CENTER
